solution: The cylinder and cone both have radius $\sqrt{3}$ and height 10.  The cylinder has volume $\pi (\sqrt{3})^2 (10)=30\pi$ and the cone has volume $(1/3) \pi (\sqrt{3})^2 (10)=10\pi$; the sum of these volumes is $\boxed{40\pi}$.
model_solution:
The base of the solid is a circle with radius $\sqrt{3}$ and the top is a cone with radius $\sqrt{3}$ and height $10$. 

The volume of the solid can be found by subtracting the volume of the cone from the volume of the cylinder.

The volume of the cylinder is $\pi (\sqrt{3})^2(10) = 30 \pi$.

The volume of the cone is $\frac{1}{3} \pi (\sqrt{3})^2(10) = \frac{10}{3} \pi \sqrt{3}.$
Subtract the volume of the cone from the volume of the cylinder to find the volume of the solid.
Subtract the volume of the cone from the volume of the cylinder to find the volume of the solid.
$30 \pi - \frac{10}{3} \pi \sqrt{3}$
$30 \pi - \frac{10}{3} \pi \sqrt{3}$
$30\pi-\frac{10}{3}\pi\sqrt{3}$
$30\pi-\frac{10}{3}\pi\sqrt{3}$
